question: In the econometric model analyzing firm performance during COVID-19, which of the following variables are used to measure the impact of government policies on firms' financial health?
options: A) Change in asset turnover (ΔSaleA)
B) Change in profit margin (ΔProfM)
C) Change in interest coverage (ΔIntrC)
D) Change in probability of default (ΔProbD)
source_files: A-shot-in-the-arm--Economic-support-packages-and-firm_2023_Journal-of-Corpor.md
question_context:
The econometric model specification is given by: 

$$ 
\Delta y_{i c,C O V I D}=\vartheta_{j}+\vartheta_{c}+\mathcal{Q}.D i s t a n c i n g_{j}\times P o l i c y_{c}+\tau.X_{i c,P r e}+\varepsilon_{i c,C O V I D} 
$$ 

where $i$ stands for firm, $j$ for sector, and $c$ for country. This is a cross-sectional regression where $\Delta y_{i c}$ , COVID is the measure of change in performance indicators for firm i in country $c$ between 2020—the latest data available—and 2019—a year prior. Following Claessens et al. (2012), we use the changes in firm-level performance indicators. Given that COVID-19 began to spread in many countries and was declared a pandemic in 2020Q1, the pattern of change in performance indicators is deemed to be due to the pandemic. 

We employ four firm performance indicators: (i) change in asset turnover $[\Delta(S a l e A)]$ , as measured by the sales-to-total-assets ratio; (ii) change in profit margin $[\Delta(P r o f M)]$ , as measured by the net-profit-to-total-revenue ratio; (iii) change in interest coverage $[\Delta(I n t r C)]$ , as measured by earnings before interest and tax divided by interest expenses; and (iv) change in probability of default $[\Delta(P r o b D)]$ , as measured by the default risk of publicly listed firms by quantitatively analyzing numerous covariates. Following Claessens et al. (2012), we employ the changes in sales-to-asset ratio and profit margin to investigate the impact of economic support packages on firm efficiency and profitability. In addition, crises have severe effects on firms' financial health in two aspects (Carletti et al., 2020): draining cash generation and liquidity that is necessary for functioning of firms and evaporating capital. Since during the public health crisis firms find it difficult to generate cash and thus could be expected to default on some obligations, we use the interest coverage ratio to determine whether policy measures help a company to pay interest on its outstanding debt. Also, following Gaganis et al. (2020) and Igan et al. (2022), we consider whether a firm will be able to continue operations, i.e. the probability of default.

question: Which of the following statements accurately describe the differences between Government Venture Capital (GVC) and Private Venture Capital (PVC) funds in their approach to funding University Spin-Offs (USOs)?
options: A) GVCs are more likely to fund USOs due to their social welfare objectives and exemption from financial pressures.
B) PVCs exhibit a strong bias against USOs because of the complexity of scientific research and lack of commercial skills among academic founders.
C) GVCs and PVCs are equally likely to fund USOs, as both recognize the signaling value of university affiliation.
D) PVCs prefer to fund USOs only at later stages, such as pre-IPO, due to financial and reputational pressures.
source_files: Venture-capital-investment-in-university-spin-offs--E_2022_Journal-of-Corpor.md
question_context:
GVCs are mainly created to correct for supply-side failures in domestic VC markets. In particular, they use or leverage public money for their operations with the aim of maximizing state welfare, such as regional economic development and job creation. They usually fund new ventures that possess promising technology that is beneficial to society but lack the necessary funding to commercialize it. Hence, GVCs need to respond to the policy objectives set by the public entity that established them. In addition, GVCs are largely exempt from financial pressure because they have unlimited lifetimes and are not subject to stringent financial return requirements. In contrast, PVCs are financial return-oriented and are subject to both financial and reputation pressures. Consequently, GVCs might be willing to devote resources to exploratory activities that give rise to inventions, while this activity might be too lengthy, too risky and too uncertain for PVCs, which would prefer to invest their resources in turning these inventions into commercially used products (Bertoni and Tykvova, 2015).

Moreover, almost all research universities in China are affiliated with the government. Hence, their connections with government departments become one of the essential social resources that can be enjoyed by USOs. This support takes the form of establishing linkages between USOs and GVCs and reducing communication costs between both parties. On the other hand, LLP-PVCs invest mainly in new ventures in the pre-IPO period to better address their higher level of contractual, financial, and reputation pressures.

question: In the context of the two-pass regression methodology for bond return prediction, which of the following statements are correct regarding the formation of expected returns?
options: A) The expected return in month t+1 is calculated using the average of estimated loadings on yield trend signals over the past 12 months.
B) The intercept in the return expectation formulation is excluded because it is the same for all bonds and does not aid in ranking.
C) The traditional momentum factor is a special case of the yield trend factor with a single signal and a beta coefficient of one.
D) The yield trend factor portfolio is constructed by sorting bonds based on their past one-year returns.
source_files: Predictive-information-in-corporate-bond-yie_2022_Journal-of-Financial-Marke.md
question_context:
The two-step procedure for extracting return expectations involves first running a cross-sectional regression of bond returns on moving average (MA) signals to obtain slope coefficients. The expected return in month t+1 is then projected using the formula: 

$$E_{t}[r_{j,t+1}]=\sum_{L}E_{t}[\beta_{L,t+1}]M A_{j t,L},$$

where $E_{t}[\beta_{L,t+1}]$ is the average of estimated loadings over the past 12 months. The intercept is excluded from the return expectation formulation as it is uniform across all bonds and thus irrelevant for ranking. The yield trend factor portfolio longs bonds with the highest expected returns and shorts those with the lowest, differing from the traditional momentum factor which uses a single past return signal and assumes a beta coefficient of one.

where $E_{t}[\beta_{L,t+1}]$ is the average of estimated loadings over the past 12 months. The intercept is excluded from the return expectation formulation as it is uniform across all bonds and thus irrelevant for ranking. The yield trend factor portfolio longs bonds with the highest expected returns and shorts those with the lowest, differing from the traditional momentum factor which uses a single past return signal and assumes a beta coefficient of one.

question: Based on the pricing model for credit risk described, which of the following factors would lead to a higher required increase in coupon rate to compensate for default costs?
options: A) Higher unconditional multiplier estimates for borrower groups
B) Lower loss severity rates on mortgages
C) Inclusion of FICO and loan characteristics in the model
D) A baseline default probability significantly below 1%
source_files: Real Estate Economics - 2007 - Firestone - The Performance of Low‐Income and Minority Mortgages.md
question_context: The pricing model for credit risk approximates baseline default probabilities using Freddie Mac history, with median loans having an LTV just under 80% and a 1-2% chance of default. Average loss severity rates are about 30%, leading to expected present value losses of 0.25-0.5% of loan balance. The required increase in coupon rate is derived by dividing the value decline by five, yielding an average annual charge of 5–10 basis points. For specific borrower groups, unconditional multiplier estimates (including severity rates) significantly impact the cost. For example, loans to blacks and Hispanics have an overall unconditional multiplier estimate around three, suggesting a cost range of 15–30 basis points. However, inclusion of FICO and loan characteristics reduces the multiplier to about 1.5, consistent with a differential of 2.5–5 basis points. The formula for converting value decline to coupon rate increase is: \[ \text{Coupon Rate Increase} = \frac{\text{Value Decline}}{5} \].

question: Under which conditions does the financial accelerator effect dominate in the equilibrium housing market model?
options: A) When house prices are high and the personal default cost $k$ is sufficiently large
B) When the risky regime is the only possible equilibrium
C) When the parameter $\beta$ is sufficiently close to 0 and $k > 1/2 - \beta$
D) When the default regime stabilizes the economy with strategic default
source_files: Collateral--credit-history--and-the-financia_2008_Journal-of-Financial-Inter.md
question_context: The financial accelerator effect is prevalent in the safe regime when house prices are high. Key conditions include $1-\frac{1+2k}{2e^{k}}<\beta$ to rule out the risky regime and ensure prices do not drop when switching to the default regime. Additionally, $k > 1/2 - \beta$ ensures borrowing cannot be risky for $p_{1d}$ close to 1, reinforcing the safe regime. The utility the good types receive in the safe regime, $\log[3+12-k2-p41pd1d] - k$, is increasing in $k$ for considered parameter values, whereas the utility in the risky regime does not depend on $k$. Thus, higher $k$ implies a greater likelihood of the safe regime with its financial accelerator.

question: Which of the following statements accurately describe the limitations and advantages of the MBF (Model-Based Frequentist) approach compared to a full-blown Bayesian approach?
options: A) The MBF approach relies on frequentist $p$-values, which do not measure model adequacy or explanatory power under alternative hypotheses.
B) A full-blown Bayesian approach explicitly compares evidence under null and alternative hypotheses, reducing the aggressiveness of null rejections.
C) The MBF approach is less aggressive than the SD-MBF because it calculates the maximum likelihood under a more constrained distributional family.
D) The SD-MBF is more useful in empirical applications as it assumes prior densities appropriate for many hypothesis testing scenarios.
source_files: The Journal of Finance - 2017 - HARVEY - Presidential Address  The Scientific Outlook in Financial Economics.md
question_context:
The MBF approach detailed above crucially depends on the frequentist $p$-value and therefore suffers from many of the same issues that plague the $p$-value itself. One such issue is that a $p$-value usually does not tell us how well a model explains the data. For example, an investment factor that has a large $t$-statistic under cross-sectional tests may not help explain the cross-section of expected returns, that is, there may be a discrepancy between statistical significance and model adequacy. Given the discussion above, this discrepancy is not hard to understand. A classical $p$-value measures the degree of incompatibility between observed data and the null hypothesis, but cannot tell us what would happen under alternative hypotheses. It is possible that both the null and the alternative hypothesis have poor explanatory power vis-a-vis the data.

In contrast, a full-blown Bayesian approach depends less on the frequentist $p$-value as it explicitly compares the evidence (i.e., likelihood) under the alternative hypotheses with the evidence under the null hypothesis. Even if we have a small frequentist $p$-value, which implies a large discrepancy between the model and the data under the null hypothesis, we may still fail to 'reject the null' under a full-blown Bayesian approach as this discrepancy could be equally large under alternative hypotheses. In other words, compared to the full-blown Bayesian approach, we may 'reject the null' too often under the MBF. This is consistent with the notion that the MBF might be too aggressive, where 'aggressive' implies more rejections of the null. However, while the MBF might be too aggressive, it still evaluates the data under alternative hypotheses. Moreover, the usual $p$-value under NHST is far more aggressive and leads to unacceptable rates of false discoveries.

question: Based on the cross-sectional regression analysis of loan modifications, which of the following variables have a statistically significant effect (at the 5% level) on the present value of modified cash flows?
options: A) ln_Bal (natural log of outstanding loan balance)
B) ln_NOI (natural log of net operating income)
C) ln_Treas10Y (natural log of 10-year treasury yield)
D) AppReduc (appraisal reduction event indicator)
source_files: Real Estate Economics - 2018 - Buschbom - Delinquencies  Default and Borrowers  Strategic Behavior toward the Modification.md
question_context: The regression results show that ln_Bal has a significant positive effect (p < 0.0001) on the present value of modified cash flows, while ln_LTV has a significant negative effect (p = 0.0012). The 10-year treasury yield (ln_Treas10Y) is negatively associated with the liability (p = 0.0004), and the appraisal reduction event (AppReduc) decreases liability (p = 0.0445). However, ln_NOI is not significant at the 5% level (p = 0.4238). Key formula: The dependent variable is the natural log of the sum of actual payments after modification, discounted at the interpolated yield for a treasury bond whose maturity corresponds to the length of a loan’s modification period, plus a risk premium.

question: In the context of signaling strategies in financial models with insider information, which of the following statements are correct regarding the optimal investment behavior of the principal (P)?
options: A) When P invests below pro-rata, he signals a high value to reduce equity issuance and increase valuations.
B) When P invests above pro-rata, he signals a low value to increase equity issuance and reduce valuations.
C) In a separating equilibrium, P's investment in the low state equals the full-information equilibrium investment.
D) The derivative of P's optimal investment with respect to the state variable X is always negative.
source_files: May-the-force-be-with-you--Investor-power-and-com_2022_Journal-of-Corporate-.md
question_context: The model examines the signaling strategies of a principal (P) with insider information in financial markets. Key formula: $K_{2}^{P*}(X)=\frac{m\left[{\mathrm{XK}}_{2}[1+\alpha^{P}]+\frac{n-m}{\gamma}[X-1]\mu_{2}\right]}{(2X-1)m+n}$, where $X=x/{\widetilde{x}}$. The principal's investment behavior depends on whether he invests below or above pro-rata. Below pro-rata $(m<{\widehat{m}})$, P signals $x_{H}$ to reduce $\beta(K_{2}^{P},\widetilde{x})$ and increase valuations. Above pro-rata $(m>{\widehat{m}})$, P signals $x_{L}$ to increase $\beta(K_{2}^{P},\widetilde{x})$ and reduce valuations. In a separating equilibrium, P's investment in the low state equals the full-information equilibrium investment: $K_{2}^{P*}(x_{L})=K_{2}^{P|\mathrm{PI}}=\frac{\mathrm{mK}_{2}[1+\alpha^{P}]}{m+n}$. The derivative $\mathrm{dK}_{2}^{P}(X)/\mathrm{dX}$ is always positive, indicating that P's optimal investment increases with the state variable X.

The derivative $\mathrm{dK}_{2}^{P}(X)/\mathrm{dX}$ is always positive, indicating that P's optimal investment increases with the state variable X.

question: In the context of BRCA1/2 genetic testing and its impact on life insurance demand, which of the following statements are supported by the empirical findings in the text?
options: A) Women who test positive for BRCA1/2 mutations exhibit lower price elasticity (λpositive = 0.45) compared to those who test negative (λnegative = 0.68).
B) The overall price elasticity of demand for term life insurance (λuntested = 0.6579) is robust across demographic categories and insensitive to age, gender, or income.
C) Respondents showed no significant change in benefit amounts when their death risk was halved, indicating high inertia in insurance demand.
D) The lapse rate for women who test positive is set conservatively at 2%, reflecting adverse selection concerns.
source_files: J of Risk   Insurance - 2007 - Viswanathan - Adverse Selection in Term Life Insurance Purchasing due to the BRCA1 2 Genetic.md
question_context: The model incorporates price and risk elasticities derived from questionnaire responses, where λpositive = 0.45 and λnegative = 0.68, reflecting differing sensitivities based on test results. The overall price elasticity λuntested = 0.6579 is stable across demographics. Formula: $$\mathcal{%}(\Delta\mathrm{Benefit})=\lambda\mathcal{%}(\Delta\mathrm{Premium})+\beta(\mathrm{ControlVariables})+\mu,$$ where the error term includes individual fixed effects. Respondents exhibited minimal benefit changes when death risk was halved (71.25% unchanged), but significant increases (+$145,600) when risk doubled. Conservative lapse rates are modeled at 2% for BRCA-positive women due to adverse selection risks, compared to 13.4% (years 1–5) and 7.5% (years 6–20) for untested/negative-test women.

question: In the context of the minimal entropy martingale measure (MEM) and exponential utility maximization, which of the following statements are correct?
options: A) The density of the MEM is proportional to the marginal utility of terminal wealth for exponential utility functions.
B) The relative entropy I(Q,P) is the supremum of the certainty equivalent of all claims w ∈ L^∞ with prices ≤ 0 under Q.
C) The optimal trading strategy H^a is always in L^∞(Ω, F_{t-1}, P; ℝ^d) for problem (3.2).
D) The MEM Q_0 coincides with the martingale measure proportional to the marginal utility of terminal wealth only if f_0 ∈ K.
source_files: Mathematical Finance - 2001 - Frittelli - The Minimal Entropy Martingale Measure and the Valuation Problem in Incomplete.md
question_context: The density of the MEM is proportional to exp(−f_0) where f_0 is a claim in C_0, suggesting it is proportional to the marginal utility of terminal wealth for exponential utility functions. The relative entropy I(Q,P) admits a dual representation, being the supremum of the certainty equivalent of all claims w ∈ L^∞ with prices ≤ 0 under Q. The exponential utility function is defined as u_a(x) = -1/a e^{-a x}, a > 0. The optimal trading strategy H^a = H*/a solves the optimality conditions of the utility maximization problem if H*_t ∈ L^∞(Ω, F_{t-1}, P; ℝ^d), implying f_0 ∈ K. However, in general, f_0 ∈ K_0 only, and the problem may not have an optimal solution in K. The MEM Q_0 coincides with the martingale measure proportional to the marginal utility of terminal wealth only under specific conditions, not universally.

However, in general, f_0 ∈ K_0 only, and the problem may not have an optimal solution in K. The MEM Q_0 coincides with the martingale measure proportional to the marginal utility of terminal wealth only under specific conditions, not universally.

question: Based on the study's findings, which of the following factors contribute to the observed reduction in relative short interest (RSI) for firms headquartered in Republican-leaning (RL) townships with Fox News availability after the 2000 Bush election?
options: A) Confirmatory bias in news consumption by RL investors
B) Home bias in equity portfolios of RL investors
C) Increased operating performance of firms in RL townships
D) Anticipation of stock price improvements by short sellers
source_files: The-influence-of-media-slant-on-short-seller_2024_Journal-of-Corporate-Finan.md
question_context: The study investigates the influence of media slant on short sellers' investment decisions, particularly focusing on the positive shift in Fox News' macroeconomic coverage post the 2000 Bush election. Key findings include a $1.3\%$ decrease in RSI for firms in RL townships with Fox availability, implying a $61.9\%$ relative reduction. The underpinnings of this result are threefold: (1) Fox's RL slant in macroeconomic news, (2) confirmatory bias in news consumption, and (3) home bias in equity portfolios. The formula for positivity in macroeconomic news coverage is given by: \[\text{Positivity} = \frac{\text{Positive words} - \text{Negative words}}{\text{Positive words} + \text{Negative words}}\]. The study employs a triple-differences regression analysis to isolate the effect of Fox's RL slant on RSI, controlling for firm and year fixed effects.

The study employs a triple-differences regression analysis to isolate the effect of Fox's RL slant on RSI, controlling for firm and year fixed effects.

question: Which of the following factors are correctly identified as influencing the call premium on fixed-rate mortgages (FRMs) according to the text?
options: A) The slope of the yield curve at the time of issue
B) The volatility in interest rates
C) The reversion speed of the spot rate to its mean-reverting value
D) The amortization schedule of the mortgage
source_files: Real Estate Economics - December 1986 - Hendershott - Mortgage Pricing  What Have We Learned So Far.md
question_context: The call premium on FRMs is influenced by several factors, including the slope of the yield curve and the volatility in interest rates. For the 1970s, the spread over the spot rate at time of issue ranged from 90 basis points (negatively-sloped yield curve) to 350 basis points (steeply positively-sloped yield curve). For the 1980s, the range was 20 to 30% greater. The higher values in the 1980s are due to a larger volatility in interest rates, although this is partially offset by a faster reversion of the spot rate to its mean-reverting value. The call premium is usually reported as the difference between the mortgage coupon and the coupon on a noncallable mortgage with the same amortization schedule as the callable mortgage, not the difference between the mortgage coupon and the spot rate.

question: In the context of CDO structures, which of the following factors contribute to the rational apathy of CDO trustees during debt workouts?
options: A) Limited financial stake in the outcome of any single company's debt
B) Diversification of CDO portfolios leading to small holdings in individual companies
C) High servicing fees that incentivize active participation in workouts
D) Lack of specialized knowledge about the debtor's business
source_files: Euro Fin Management - 2008 - Hu - Debt  Equity and Hybrid Decoupling  Governance and Systemic Risk Implications.md
question_context: CDO trustees may have limited incentives to be actively involved in workouts. First, the trustee is a largely empty creditor. It has an interest in preserving the future stream of trustee fees, and may have a long-term reputational interest in behaving sensibly, but will typically have no other financial interest in the outcome. Second, many CDOs vehicles diversify widely, and own only a small piece of any one company’s debt. Thus, the CDO trustee has a limited stake in a single company. Rational apathy, in which the trustee never acquires the information needed for an informed decision, and free rides on the efforts of larger creditors, could sometimes be the privately rational strategy, just as apathy is rational for many small shareholders. Third, debt workouts require close knowledge of the debtor’s business, and sometimes the willingness to lend additional amounts. CDO trustees often won’t have the necessary knowledge, nor the ability to commit additional capital. Fourth, CDO trustees, like bond indenture trustees generally, are typically paid limited fees for a limited role, which may not cover the people cost of complex workout negotiations (out-of-pocket costs are typically recoverable from pool assets). To be sure, as workouts become more common, market practice is adjusting – some CDOs provide for higher servicing fees for troubled pools; and some trustees now specialise in CDO workouts.

question: According to the study on merger control legislation in European banking, which of the following factors are significantly associated with changes in target announcement premia?
options: A) Reduction in mergers creating 'too-big-to-fail' (TBTF) banks
B) Increase in market power through geographic consolidation
C) Improvements in cost efficiency post-merger
D) Changes in the probability of merger consummation
source_files: The-impacts-of-stricter-merger-legislation-on-bank-me_2021_Journal-of-Financ.md
question_context: The study analyzes the impact of merger control legislation on bank mergers in 15 European countries from 1986 to 2007. Key findings include an increase in target announcement premia by 6–7 percentage points (14–16 percentage points for control-shift mergers) after legislative changes. The authors attribute this to a reduction in TBTF mergers, defined as those where the merged bank's assets exceed a certain share of the country's GDP. TBTF mergers were associated with 12–15 percentage points lower premia. The study also examines market power through geographic and industry overlap proxies, finding some evidence of reduced bank-to-bank mergers but no significant change in cross-border transactions. Formula: ΔPremia ≈ -β⋅TBTF + γ⋅MarketPower, where β > 0 and γ is context-dependent.

question: According to the comparative analysis of national tort systems, which of the following factors are identified as significantly influencing the divergence between the U.S. tort liability system and those of other countries?
options: A) The availability of first-party insurance and government benefits
B) The distinction between civil law and common law systems
C) The influence of media attention and political groups
D) The rapid adjustment of common law systems to social changes
source_files: J of Risk   Insurance - 2009 - Kerr - A Cross‐National Study of Government Social Insurance as an Alternative to Tort.md
question_context: The text highlights that while important differences exist among civil law countries in Western Europe, these differences are minor compared to the divergence between the U.S. experience and the rest of the world. The Academy of Comparative Law and the European Group on Tort Law both emphasize the role of first-party insurance, including government benefits, and the influence of media attention and powerful political groups in the U.S. as key factors. The civil code versus common law difference is also discussed, but the reports highlight the great variation found across both civil codes and common law systems, suggesting that institutions themselves, rather than the rules, are the dominant forces. Key formula: Litigation rate = f(social welfare generosity, media influence, political group power).

question: Based on the empirical evidence from the augmented rent equations and structural probit estimates, which of the following statements are correct regarding lease contract preferences?
options: A) Larger tenants show a significant preference for lease contracts without relocation options due to potential business disruption costs.
B) Out-of-state tenants and existing tenants have a statistically significant impact on the choice of lease contracts.
C) Tenants with above-average credit risk display a preference for lease contracts with relocation options.
D) The price elasticity for lease contracts without relocation options ranges between -0.1699 and -0.0539.
source_files: Real Estate Economics - June 1992 - Benjamin - Influence of Rent Differentials on the Choice between Office Rent Contracts.md
question_context: The empirical results indicate that rents are significantly related to square footage of office space, square feet of space squared, type of tenant, lease characteristics, attractive location, lease term in years, and size of security deposit at the 0.05 level. The adjusted $R^{2}\mathbf{s}$ are 0.57 and 0.28, respectively, indicating substantial unexplained variation in $r_{1}$. Key findings include that $r_{i}$ declines at an increasing rate with square footage, landlords charge out-of-state tenants higher rates due to asymmetric information, and tenants pay a premium for default aversion. The structural probit estimates show that the choice of office lease contracts is significantly affected by tenant characteristics and lease characteristics. The price variable $\hat{r}_{1i}-\hat{r}_{2i}$ has a negative and significant relationship with the choice of lease contracts, with price elasticities between $-0.1699$ and $-0.0539$. Larger tenants prefer lease contracts without relocation options (coefficient: 0.2318), while above-average creditworthy tenants prefer contracts with relocation options (coefficient: -0.7850, $t=-2.10$).

question: In the context of incomplete information on a firm's asset value, which of the following statements are correct regarding the pricing of corporate securities?
options: A) The valuation of corporate securities leads to a nonlinear filtering problem due to noisy asset information.
B) A deterministic relationship between equity and asset value can still be assumed for equity-based estimators.
C) The conditional distribution of the current asset value given the investor's information up to time t can be approximated using a Markov chain approximation.
D) Equity-based intensity estimates are reliable even when incomplete information effects are neglected.
source_files: Mathematical Finance - 2009 - Frey - PRICING CORPORATE SECURITIES UNDER NOISY ASSET INFORMATION.md
question_context: The paper considers the pricing of corporate securities of a given firm, in particular equity, when investors do not have full information on the firm’s asset value. Under noisy asset information, the pricing of corporate securities leads to a nonlinear filtering problem. This problem is solved by a Markov chain approximation, leading to an efficient finite-dimensional approximative filter for the asset value. The model assumes that the firm pays dividends and postulates a noisy relation between asset value and dividend size. Equity value is modeled as expected discounted value of future dividends until default, both under full information (observable asset value process) and under incomplete information. The asset value process $V$ follows the stochastic differential equation: $$d V_{t}=\mu_{V}V_{t-}d t+\sigma_{V}V_{t-}d W_{t}-\kappa d D_{t},$$ where $\mu_{V}\in\mathbb{R},\kappa\in[0,1],\sigma_{V}>0$ and $W$ is a Brownian motion.

question: Which of the following statements are correct regarding the instrumental variables used in the analysis of wealth effects in mergers?
options: A) Surprise deal dummy is significant for Combined CAR but not for rival CARs.
B) Delaware incorporation intensity affects rival wealth effects but has no direct link to antitrust intervention.
C) Industry-adjusted stock payment percentage reflects firm-level information and influences wealth effects.
D) Tender offer dummy is directly related to anticompetitive motives and thus affects antitrust intervention.
source_files: What-determines-horizontal-merger-antitrust-case_2017_Journal-of-Corporate-F.md
question_context: Key formula: The abnormal return is calculated using the market model: $$A R_{i t}=R_{i t}-\widehat{\alpha}_{i}-\widehat{\beta}_{i}R_{m t},$$ where $R_{m t}$ is the CRSP equally-weighted market index return on day t, $R_{i t}$ is firm i's return on day t and $\widehat{\alpha_{i}}$ and $\widehat{\beta_{i}}$ are coefficients from the market model estimated over 250 trading days starting from day $-300$ before the announcement date (day 0). The analysis uses the cumulative abnormal return from two days before to two days after the merger announcement, i.e., $C A R(-2,2)$. For Combined CAR, instrumental variables include Surprise deal dummy, Tender offer dummy, Hostile takeover dummy, Industry-adjusted stock payment percentage, and Bidder past performance. Surprise deal dummy equals one if there are no horizontal mergers in the merging industry in the previous three years. Tender offer dummy equals one if a deal is a tender offer and zero otherwise. Industry-adjusted stock payment percentage relates to bidder market valuation, growth, business complementarity, and information asymmetry. Delaware incorporation intensity is the proportion of industry rivals incorporated in Delaware, which affects rival wealth effects but does not directly relate to antitrust intervention.

question: In the context of the BEKK-GARCH(1,1) model applied to DEM/USD and GBP/USD exchange rate series, which of the following statements are empirically supported by the analysis?
options: A) The kurtosis of standardized residuals is larger than that of unstandardized residuals, rejecting the normality hypothesis.
B) The empirical autocorrelations of exchange rate series exhibit long memory, which is perfectly captured by the GARCH(1,1) model.
C) The coherence between squared residuals of DEM/USD and GBP/USD decreases sharply at very low frequencies under both empirical and Gaussian assumptions.
D) The causality measures indicate that instantaneous causality in volatility is stronger than unidirectional causality for daily data.
source_files: Fourth Moment Structure of Multivariate GARCH Models.md
question_context: The BEKK-GARCH(1,1) model was fitted to bivariate residual series of DEM/USD and GBP/USD exchange rates. Key findings include: The kurtosis of standardized residuals $\hat{\xi}_{t}$ is larger than the kurtosis of the unstandardized residuals, 6.10 and 5.95, respectively, so that the normality hypothesis is clearly rejected. The coherence between the squared residuals of DEM/USD and GBP/USD decreases sharply at very low frequencies, then increases and remains on the same level, about 0.34 and 0.43, respectively, at medium and high frequencies. Causality measures show that the unidirectional causalities are much weaker than the instantaneous causality, with $\mathcal{C V}_{\mathrm{DEM/USD\cdot\leftrightarrow{GBP/USD}}}=0.5508$ under empirical measures.

question: In the study of debit card effects on savings behavior, which of the following statements are supported by the empirical results?
options: A) The proportion of beneficiaries who saved in their accounts increased immediately after receiving debit cards.
B) The stock of savings showed no significant change in the first few periods after card receipt.
C) The average savings effect after two years with the card was approximately 2.0% of annual income.
D) Beneficiaries who started saving deposited significantly more in subsequent periods compared to the first period.
source_files: The Journal of Finance - 2021 - BACHAS - How Debit Cards Enable the Poor to Save More.md
question_context:
The study examines the dynamic effects of debit cards on transactions and savings using administrative data from 348,802 accounts. Key findings include an immediate increase in withdrawals post-card receipt and a gradual rise in savings. The stock of savings showed small initial effects (100-200 pesos) but grew substantially over time, reaching 768 pesos (2.0% of annual income) after two years. The proportion of beneficiaries saving increased from 13% pre-card to 87% after two years. The formula for the regression model is:

$$
y_{i}=\alpha+\gamma\mathbb{I}(\mathbf{Card}\geq\mathrm{median~time})_{i}+u_{i},
$$

where $u_{i}$ is clustered at the locality level. The study also decomposes savings effects into extensive (proportion saving) and intensive (amount saved) margins, showing that beneficiaries deposited 618 pesos (4.9% of income) in their first saving period but less thereafter.

question: Which of the following conditions are essential for the error estimates and convergence results of the Longstaff–Schwartz algorithm as stated in Theorem 5.1 and Theorem 5.6?
options: A) The approximation architectures must be convex and closed subsets of L²(S, ρₖ).
B) The VC-dimension of the approximation architectures must be finite.
C) The payoff functions must be uniformly bounded in L∞.
D) The approximation architectures must be dense in L²(S, ρₖ) for almost sure convergence.
source_files: Mathematical Finance - 2016 - Zanger - CONVERGENCE OF A LEAST‐SQUARES MONTE CARLO ALGORITHM FOR AMERICAN OPTION PRICING.md
question_context:
The key objective of this subsection is the statement of our new sample (stochastic) error estimates and convergence results, Theorems 5.1 and 5.6 as well as their associated corollaries, for the Longstaff–Schwartz algorithm (using a single set of Monte Carlo paths) with approximation architectures that need not be either convex or closed. We work explicitly in all of Section 5 within the setting of Sections 2 and 3, employing the notations introduced there. To present our results, first define 

$$||g||_{u}=\operatorname*{sup}\{|g(s)||s\in S\}$$

for any real-valued function $g$ defined on $s$ , and also set 

$$L=\operatorname*{max}\{1,\vert\vert Z_{1}\vert\vert_{u},\dots,\vert\vert Z_{K}\vert\vert_{u}\}.$$

Theorem 5.1, which we formally state next, gives error estimates involving the expected approximation errors $\begin{array}{r}{\mathbf{E}(\operatorname*{inf}_{f\in\mathcal{H}_{k}}||f{\mathbf{-E}}(Z_{\hat{\tau}_{k+1}(X_{(k+1)N})}|X_{k})||_{L^{2}(\rho_{k})})}\end{array}$ , $k=1,\ldots,K-1$ , corresponding to the approximate continuation values. Theorem 5.1 can be used, for example, to prove almost sure convergence of the Longstaff–Schwartz algorithm, a result we present as Corollary 5.5 below. In any case, we will use Theorem 5.1 within the proof of Theorem 5.6, which gives error estimates involving the approximation errors of the exact continuation values.

question: Which of the following statements are valid criticisms of using ex post variance as a measure of risk in portfolio selection under uncertainty?
options: A) Variance estimates are ambiguous due to multiple possible calculations from the same price series
B) Variance rankings of firms change depending on the chosen estimation method
C) Variance requires normal and stationary distributions of returns to be meaningful
D) Variance calculations equally weight all observations within the chosen time period
source_files: The Journal of Finance - March 1970 - Joyce - THE UNCERTAINTY IN RISK  IS VARIANCE UNAMBIGUOUS.md
question_context:
The great majority of studies on risk, and portfolio diversification, and capital asset pricing under uncertainty have adopted variance as the measure of risk. However, we have argued that variance calculated ex post is ambiguous in that there is more than one variance associated with each series of stock prices. Moreover, our two experiments have revealed that these different variances give conflicting results, as the ranking of firms depends on which variance estimate is chosen. Of course, if we lived in a world where the distributions of expected returns (stock prices in the present case) were both normal and stationary, such problems would not arise, but our experiments suggest that this is not the situation.

The question of the time period over which to calculate variance is principally related to the problem of making ex ante decisions from ex post data. Taking a particular time interval for computation equally weights all the observations within that period, while other observations receive no weight. This may not be the optimal technique for forming expectations of the future from past information.

question: Which of the following statements are empirically supported regarding the impact of partisan conflict on corporate credit spreads for politically connected firms?
options: A) A one-standard-deviation increase in partisan conflict leads to a statistically significant increase in credit spreads for High PD companies.
B) The effects of partisan conflict are more pronounced for investment-grade bonds than speculative-grade bonds.
C) The joint effect of partisan conflict and political connection is significant, while neither factor alone has a substantial impact.
D) Macroeconomic control variables fully subsume the influence of partisan conflict on credit spreads.
source_files: Partisan-conflict-and-corporate-credit-spreads--The-_2024_Journal-of-Corpora.md
question_context:
The study examines the impact of partisan conflict on corporate credit spreads for politically connected firms, defined by high political donations (High PD) or high government spending exposure (High GSE). Key findings include: a one-standard-deviation increase in partisan conflict leads to an 8.96 bps increase in credit spreads for High PD firms (t-statistic = 3.37) and a 7.45 bps increase for High GSE industries (t-statistic = 2.68). The regression model is given by:

$$\Delta CSIndex_t = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \text{Partisan conflict}_{t-1}^D + \beta_2 CSIndex_{t-1} + \beta_3 \text{Macro control}_t + \varepsilon_t$$

Additionally, the interaction effect between High PC (partisan conflict) and High PD/GSE is significant (coefficient = 4.15, t-statistic = 3.37), while neither factor alone has a significant coefficient. This confirms that the joint effect of partisan conflict and political connection drives credit spread variation.

question: Which of the following statements are empirically supported by the clawback adoption data and risk-reduction hypothesis?
options: A) Clawback provisions primarily target CEOs, with only 1.4% explicitly covering non-employee board members
B) 76.6% of clawback policies use earnings restatements as a triggering event, creating incentives for conservative financial policies
C) The Vega of executive portfolios is positively correlated with accounting restatements, making clawbacks an effective risk-mitigation tool
D) Dodd-Frank's three-year limitation period is adopted by 31.6% of firms, while SOX's one-year period is used by 43.9%
source_files: Clawback Provisions and Firm Risk.md
question_context: Key findings from the clawback sample analysis: The most common triggering event is an accounting restatement (76.6%), with Vega incentives positively related to misreporting (Burns & Kedia 2006; Efendi et al. 2007). Panel F shows statute of limitations adoption rates: 43.9% for SOX's 1-year period versus 31.6% for Dodd-Frank's 3-year period. The risk-reduction hypothesis posits that clawbacks discourage risky investments through three mechanisms: (i) direct penalty for triggering outcomes, (ii) conservative policy channels, and (iii) reduced performance variability. Formula: $\text{Vega} = \frac{\partial \text{Executive Wealth}}{\partial \sigma}$ where $\sigma$ is the firm's stock return volatility.

question: Which of the following statements are correct regarding the analysis of trading activity and returns around macroeconomic announcements in the S&P 500 futures markets?
options: A) The GLOBEX trade data include all trades, even those occurring at the same price, unlike standard time and sales data.
B) The CTR data for regular S&P 500 futures during regular trading hours provide accurate trade timestamps without any noise.
C) The regression model used to identify impactful macroeconomic announcements includes dummy variables to control for intraday volatility variation.
D) The Employment Situation announcement has the highest statistically significant impact on price volatility among the considered announcements.
source_files: Trading-around-macroeconomic-announcements--Are-_2006_Journal-of-Financial-I.md
question_context:
We examine trading activity and returns around the announcements in the regular and E-mini S&P 500 futures markets. The GLOBEX trade data include all trades even when consecutive trades occur at the same price, while the standard time and sales data used in most of the existing studies of futures markets include only trades that result in price changes. Accurate trade timestamps are important in the analysis of the trading activity around the announcements. When the trade times are imputed by the CTR algorithm, trades for which accurate execution time is not determined are assigned to the beginning of 15-minute brackets based on trader cards. As a result, a significant amount of noise is introduced into the beginning of every 15-minute interval.

The dates of macroeconomic news releases are obtained from the database on macroeconomic announcements and forecasts collected by Money Market Services (MMS) International. The regression model used to identify impactful macroeconomic announcements is given by:

$$
K_{i t}=\gamma_{0}+\sum_{t=1}^{T-1}\gamma_{t}D_{t}+\sum_{m=1}^{M}\eta_{m}D_{m i t}+e_{i t},
$$

where $K_{i t}$ is price volatility measured as absolute return on day $i$ in the five minute interval t ; $D_{m i t}$ is a dummy variable that is equal to one if the announcement $m$ is made on day $i$ in the beginning of interval $t$ ; and $D_{t}$ is a dummy variable used to control for the intraday variation in volatility. The average impact of the most influential announcement (Employment Situation) is about 37.2 basis points, while the average impact of the least influential announcement (Factory Inventories) is about 4.5 basis points.

question: Which of the following statements are supported by the preliminary evidence on the relative riskiness of municipal and corporate bonds?
options: A) The variances of return for portfolios of comparably rated bonds are virtually identical.
B) The covariances of comparably rated bond portfolios with an index of common stock returns are very close.
C) Municipal bonds are inherently riskier than corporate bonds due to their tax-exempt status.
D) The yield ratio (municipal to corporate) accurately reflects the marginal tax bracket without any risk adjustment.
source_files: The Journal of Finance - May 1983 - SKELTON - Relative Risk in Municipal and Corporate Debt.md
question_context: This preliminary investigation of relative risk in municipal and corporate bonds reveals that in at least two respects they are remarkably similar. First, the measured variances of return for portfolios of comparably rated bonds are virtually identical. Second, the covariances of comparably rated bond portfolios with an index of common stock returns are also very close to one another. Some have argued that because municipals are risker than corporates, the yield ratio (municipal to corporate) understates the actual marginal tax bracket at work across the bonds. But since these risk differences are not discernable, the relative yields may be truly informative about the tax brackets of the marginal holders of the bonds.

question: Under the Arbitrage Pricing Theory (APT), which of the following conditions must hold to ensure the absence of asymptotic arbitrage opportunities?
options: A) The variance of the portfolio's excess returns must asymptotically approach zero.
B) The expected excess return of the portfolio must be uniformly bounded away from zero.
C) The weighted sum of squared pricing errors must be uniformly bounded.
D) The factor loadings matrix must be of full rank for all finite subsets of assets.
source_files: The Journal of Finance - September 1984 - INGERSOLL - Some Results in the Theory of Arbitrage Pricing.md
question_context:
The primary tools for investigation of the APT are large portfolios with little or no residual risk. A riskless arbitrage opportunity exists with the portfolio $\pmb{\alpha}$ if:

$$\begin{array}{c}{{\mathrm{Var}(\alpha^{\prime}\tilde{x})=\alpha^{\prime}(\Omega+B B^{\prime})\alpha=0}}\ {{E(\alpha^{\prime}\tilde{x}-r)=\alpha^{\prime}a>0.}}\end{array}$$

In an infinite economy, asymptotic arbitrage opportunities might exist. A sequence of portfolios is said to generate an asymptotic arbitrage opportunity if along some subsequence:

$$\begin{array}{r}{\operatorname*{lim}_{\nu\rightarrow\infty}\nabla\mathbf{ar}(\alpha_{\nu}^{\prime}\tilde{{x}})=0}\end{array}$$

$$\alpha_{\nu}^{\prime}a\geq\delta>0\mathrm{for~all}\nu.$$

The basic pricing relation is based on the premise of an absence of asymptotic arbitrage opportunities. Specifically, there exists a positive number $V$ such that the weighted sum of the squared pricing errors is uniformly bounded:

$$(a_{n}-B_{n}\lambda_{n})^{\prime}\Omega_{n}^{-1}(a_{n}-B_{n}\lambda_{n})\leq V<\infty\quad\mathrm{for~all~}n.$$

question: Which of the following statements accurately describe the shifts in the relative shares of instalment credit held by financial institutions from 1949 to 1958?
options: A) Credit unions consistently increased their share of instalment credit each year during this period.
B) Commercial banks experienced a decline in their share of instalment credit from 1950 to 1955, followed by relative stability.
C) Sales finance companies saw their share of instalment credit increase from 1949 to 1958, peaking in 1955.
D) Consumer finance companies maintained a relatively stable share of instalment credit, fluctuating between 11% and 12% after 1951.
source_files: The Journal of Finance - May 1960 - Dauten - RECENT INSTITUTIONAL DEVELOPMENTS IN THE FIELD OF CONSUMER CREDIT.md
question_context:
While the shift in instalment financing from retail outlets to financial institutions was taking place, some significant changes also occurred in the relative shares of such financing done by various financial institutions. The most pronounced of these changes has been the increased share of instalment financing of consumers done by credit unions. At the end of 1949, credit unions held 4.8 per cent of instalment credit outstanding. Their share went up steadily until, at the end of 1958, it was 9.3 per cent of the total. It increased as a proportion of the total each year except in 1955, when the percentage at the end of the year was the same as at the end of the previous year.

There were significant shifts from 1949 through 1958 in the percentage of instalment credit held by commercial banks. Their proportion of credit outstanding dropped from 1950 to 1955, from 49.1 per cent of the total at the end of 1950 to 43.3 per cent at the end of 1955. It remained about the same in 1956 and has increased slightly since then. This performance of commercial banks can best be summarized by saying that their share of total instalment credit declined from 1950 to 1955 and has remained about stable since then.

question: Which of the following factors contributed to the increased demand for consumer durable goods in the post-World War II period?
options: A) Depleted stocks of durable consumer goods at the end of the war
B) High levels of consumer debt and debt service charges
C) Development of more lenient credit terms
D) Shifts from business ownership to consumer ownership of durable goods
source_files: The Journal of Finance - May 1954 - Jones - SOME ASPECTS OF DEMAND FOR CONSUMER DURABLE GOODS.md
question_context:
In retrospect, it appears that, at the end of World War II, conditions were ripe for a great expenditure for consumer durable goods. Real personal disposable income in 1946 was 48 per cent greater than in 1939 and 59 per cent greater than in 1929. The real value of the stock of liquid assets at the end of 1945 was 116 per cent greater than in 1939. But the stock of housing and the flow of housing services had lagged far behind. The real value of the stock of automobiles was probably even less than in 1929 or 1939. The supplying of a flow of durable goods consumption services comparable to the flow in 1929 and 1939 called for a stupendous increase of the stock of housing, automobiles, and other durable goods. The postwar period has called for building up stock to a level providing services appropriate not only to the 1946 level of income, but also to the increases in real income since that time. Real disposable income in 1953 was 94 per cent greater than in 1929 and 81 per cent greater than in 1939. If the demand for services of houses and other durable goods increased accordingly, it was necessary to nearly double the stock of these goods which we had at these earlier dates.

Even if real disposable income had not been higher at, and after, the end of World War II than before the war, the depletion of stocks during the war made for a much greater demand for accretions to the stock than before the war. The demand contributed to higher income and for still greater demand for the services of the goods and, therefore, for still further increases in the stocks of the goods.

In addition to the depleted stocks of durable consumer goods at the end of the war, large stocks of liquid assets, and high levels of income, some other factors have probably contributed to an increase in the stock of consumer durable goods necessary to meet the demand for their services. Consumer debt and debt service charges were at a very low level. Consumer house debt at the end of 1945 was equal to 12 per cent of disposable income compared with 16 per cent in 1940 and service charges on the debt to 2 per cent in 1945 compared with 3 per cent in 1940. The amount of other consumer instalment debt was 2 per cent of disposable income in 1945 compared with 7 per cent in 1940, while the repayments were 3 compared with 10 per cent. One could then say that the consumers had a drawing account of roughly $\$7$ billion of mortgage credit, and $\$9$ billion of other instalment credit before reaching their 1940 position.

question: Based on the analysis of regional variations in instalment credit usage, which of the following statements are supported by the data?
options: A) The South has a higher proportion of spending units with instalment debt than the national average
B) Credit unions are most popular in the Northeast region
C) Retail outlets are used more for instalment credit in the South and West compared to other regions
D) Finance companies have below-average usage in the Northeast region
source_files: The Journal of Finance - December 1960 - Croteau - SOURCES OF CONSUMER CREDIT  INSTALMENT DEBT AMONG INSTITUTIONAL.md
question_context: The data shows substantially less instalment debt in the north-central and northeastern regions (less than 40% of spending units), while over half of spending units in the South and West have some instalment debt. Key regional patterns include: banks being used slightly more than average in three regions except north-central; finance companies being used relatively less in the Northeast; credit unions being extremely popular in the West (almost double national average) but below-average in the South; retail outlets being used more in South and West; and car dealers being more important in the South. The formula for regional distribution is: Regional Percentage = (Regional Instalment Debt / Total Instalment Debt) × 100.

question: In the generalized n-bond model, which of the following conditions ensure that the equilibrium vector of bond prices equals the expected prices under homogeneous expectations?
options: A) Investors have identical expectations and risk preferences
B) The matrix of variances and co-variances is diagonal
C) Investors are equally audacious and confident in their forecasts
D) The capital account constraint is non-binding
source_files: The Journal of Finance - March 1965 - Bierwag - ON CAPITAL ASSET PRICES  COMMENT.md
question_context:
The generalized n-bond model extends the two-bond framework, where the value of the investor's capital account is given by:

$$\bf V_{t}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}p_{j}x_{j}$$

and its expected value and variance are derived from:

$$\begin{array}{l}{\overline{{\mathbf{v}}}=\pmb{\Sigma}_{\pmb{\mathrm{f}}_{\mathbf{j}}\mathbf{x}_{\mathbf{j}}}^{\mathbf{Z}}}\\ {\mathbf{S}^{\mathbf{2}}=\pmb{\Sigma}_{\mathbf{j}}\pmb{\Sigma}_{\mathbf{k}}^{\mathbf{Z}}\pmb{\mathrm{x}}_{\mathbf{j}}\pmb{\mathrm{x}}_{\mathbf{k}}\pmb{\sigma}_{\mathbf{j}\mathbf{k}}}\end{array}$$

Maximizing utility subject to constraints yields equilibrium bond prices:

$$\mathbb{P}^{\mathrm{e}}=\Big(\sum_{\mathrm{s}=1}^{\mathrm{m}}\mu_{\mathrm{s}}\mathsf{M}_{\mathrm{s}}^{-1}\Big)^{-1}\sum_{\mathrm{s}=1}^{\mathrm{m}}\mu_{\mathrm{s}}\mathsf{M}_{\mathrm{s}}^{-1}\mathrm{~E~}\mathfrak{P}_{\mathrm{s}}$$

Homogeneous expectations imply $\mathbf{P^{e}}=\mathbf{E}\boldsymbol{\varphi}_{:}$, while differing but equally confident expectations lead to $\mathbf{P^{e}}=\mathbf{n}^{-1}\underset{\mathbf{s}}{\underbrace{\texttt{I C E}}}\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{\mathbf{s}}$.

question: In the context of Value-Reducing Defensive Strategies (VRDS), which of the following conditions are necessary for VRDS to be effective in increasing target shareholders' welfare?
options: A) The strategy must be discriminatory, reducing the target's value more for some bidders than others
B) The strategy must be expensive to redeem to prevent the target from withdrawing it once competition develops
C) The strategy must be non-discriminatory to ensure equal treatment of all bidders
D) The strategy must be inexpensive to redeem to allow flexibility in negotiations
source_files: The Journal of Finance - March 1990 - BERKOVITCH - How Target Shareholders Benefit from Value‐Reducing Defensive Strategies.md
question_context:
The paper analyzes resistance strategies that work by reducing the value of synergy gains for some bidders and shows how these strategies improve target shareholder welfare. Key conditions for VRDS effectiveness include: 1) being discriminatory, so they reduce the target's value to some bidders more than to others, and 2) being expensive to redeem, as otherwise the target has an incentive to withdraw them once competition has developed. The formula for the minimal VRDS needed to induce entry is given by: 

$$r\biggl(L-{\frac{c}{r}}\biggr)+q r L+q^{2}\biggl(H-{\frac{c}{r}}\biggr)\geq q^{2}H+q r L+r b.$$

This shows the payoff comparison for the target when deciding whether to use VRDS. The paper provides multiple real-world examples where such strategies were employed successfully in takeover battles.

question: In the context of the regression analysis examining corporate governance and firm efficiency, which of the following variables are found to have a statistically significant positive impact on technical efficiency (TE) scores?
options: A) Bosize (Board size)
B) Audind (Proportion of independent nonexecutive directors on the audit committee)
C) Audexp (Proportion of financial expert seats on the audit committee)
D) Tenure (Average number of years directors have been on the board)
source_files: J of Risk   Insurance - 2011 - Huang - Corporate Governance and Efficiency  Evidence From U S  Property Liability Insurance.md
question_context:
The regression model is specified as: 

$$\begin{array}{r l}&{E S_{i t}=\alpha+\beta_{1}B o s i z e_{i t}+\beta_{2}A u d i n d_{i t}+\beta_{3}A u d e x p_{i t}+\beta_{4}T e n u r e_{i t}+\beta_{5}B l o c k_{i t}}\ &{\qquad+\beta_{6}C o n m g t_{i t}+\beta_{7}C o n d i r_{i t}+\beta_{8}I n s i d e r_{i t}+\beta_{9}A u d i t d e p e n d e n c e_{i t}+\beta_{10}S i z e_{i t}}\end{array}$$

The results for Panel A, model 1 show that Bosize, Audind, Tenure, and Insider are positive and significantly related to the original TEs. The positive coefficient of Bosize suggests that the larger the board size, the higher the efficiency score. The positive relation between firm efficiency and board size is consistent with Golden and Zajac (2001), who find that board size is positively related to corporate performance. The positive coefficient of Audind suggests that the independence requirement for audit committees required by SOX benefits firm efficiency. We find Audexp is negatively and statistically related to the efficiency scores, implying that having too many financial expert seats on the audit committee is harmful to audit committee effectiveness. The coefficient of Tenure is positive and statistically significant, suggesting the longer the directors are on the board, the more efficient the firms become.

The coefficient of Tenure is positive and statistically significant, suggesting the longer the directors are on the board, the more efficient the firms become.

question: In the context of fire-sale spillovers and systemic risk, which of the following factors are identified as primary contributors to the Aggregate Vulnerability (AV) index's precrisis increase?
options: A) Size and leverage of banks
B) Delevering speed and concentration of illiquid assets
C) Market-to-book ratio and stock return volatility
D) Regulatory capital requirements and GDP growth
source_files: The Journal of Finance - 2021 - DUARTE - Fire‐Sale Spillovers and Systemic Risk.md
question_context: The AV index decomposes additively into each bank’s 'systemicness' (its contribution to a fire sale) and multiplicatively into aggregate and cross-sectional factors that drive fire-sale vulnerability. We highlight the fire-sale-specific factors of delevering speed and concentration of illiquid assets that jointly account for 60% of AV growth and 50% of its variance between the beginning of our sample in 1999 and the third quarter of 2008, when AV peaks. Size and leverage—known factors of systemic risk—show the expected trends, increasing in the precrisis period and decreasing toward the end of the sample. The two factors that we identify as specific to fire-sale spillovers—leverage adjustment speed and illiquidity concentration—also play important roles in the evolution of AV and in the cross-section of bank systemicness.

question: In the numerical experiments for pricing American exchange style options, which of the following statements are supported by the results?
options: A) The corrected weights algorithm (3.14) reduces relative errors by factors of 30 to 50 for 6-month maturities across all dimensions.
B) The relative errors for both algorithms (2.4) and (3.14) never exceed 4% for 12-month maturities and 2% for 6-month maturities.
C) The use of corrected terms in dimension 10 is highly effective for maturities of 9 and 12 months, reducing errors below 1%.
D) Optimal grid selection is crucial in high dimensions due to the computational intractability of weight corrections.
source_files: Mathematical Finance - 2003 - Bally - First‐Order Schemes in the Numerical Quantization Method.md
question_context:
The numerical experiments focus on pricing American exchange style options using algorithms (2.4) and (3.14) in dimensions 4, 6, and 10. The payoff function is given by:

$$h(t,S_{t})=\big(S_{t}^{1}\ldots S_{t}^{d/2}-S_{t}^{d/2+1}\ldots S_{t}^{d}\big)_{+},$$

where the price process follows a Black-Scholes model with specific parameters. The results show that relative errors do not exceed 4% for 12 months and 2% for 6 months. Corrected weights are particularly effective for 6-month maturities, reducing errors by factors of 30 to 50. However, in dimension 10, the use of corrected terms for longer maturities (9 and 12 months) is less effective due to the difficulty in optimizing grids and the high storage costs involved.

question: According to the analysis of asset redeployment and nonrecourse secured debt, which of the following statements are correct regarding the efficiency of financial contracts?
options: A) Nonrecourse secured debt avoids ex post bargaining by making the redeployer a residual claimant to the asset's highest feasible bad-state value.
B) Ex post bargaining over transfer prices leads to optimal investment levels by both the entrepreneur and the redeployer.
C) Financial leases with embedded call options can achieve state-contingent ownership similar to nonrecourse secured debt.
D) Perfect competition among redeployers ensures that ex ante investments are not distorted by ex post bargaining.
source_files: The Journal of Finance - 2002 - Habib - The Financing and Redeployment of Specific Assets.md
question_context: An asset redeployer must identify an asset’s next best use and be prepared to repossess and resale it to a member of the class of next best users. We hypothesize that in some cases there is a real trade-off between the costs identifying the asset’s next best use, ex ante, and the ex post costs of repossession and resale, so that some level of ex ante investment is efficient. Where ex ante investments are noncontractible, nonrecourse secured debt avoids ex post bargaining and appropriately bonds the redeployer’s performance by making him a residual claimant to the asset’s highest feasible bad-state value. This analysis applies to the activities of other intermediaries as well. Implicit in the lender’s identification of the asset’s next best use is an assessment of its value in the critical state that separates the good and bad states. This value establishes the face amount of the loan. As with the full scope of redeployment activities, accurate valuation looked at in isolation may be noncontractible and subject to gains from ex ante investment. If valuation is left until the bad state occurs, for example, a sales agent will have too little incentive to search for a better price because he captures only a share of the gains. And the entrepreneur benefits from an ex ante valuation of the primary use of the asset to better determine his optimal level of investment. The model’s results fit nicely with the events following airline deregulation. Many aircraft loans met with default by failing carriers, and many carriers voluntarily relinquished aircraft. Although several carriers sought protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code, secured lenders often succeeded in repossessing and redeploying the aircraft that served as collateral. It is interesting to note that Section 1110 of the Bankruptcy Code now specifically exempts aircraft and vessels from Chapter 11’s stay of a secured creditor’s lien under certain circumstances. Whatever the motivation for Section 1110, it surely has the effects of reducing the costs of redeployment by aircraft finance firms and, all else equal, increasing the amount they are willing to lend by increasing the aircrafts’ critical state value.

question: Which of the following statements are valid critiques or extensions of the traditional theory of money creation as discussed in the text?
options: A) The theory ignores banks' role as profit-maximizing firms, treating their behavior mechanically.
B) The public's preferences and shifts between currency and deposits play a crucial role in determining total deposits.
C) The theory adequately incorporates the multidimensional nature of deposit yields and services.
D) The focus on nominal quantity of deposits as bank output is problematic due to its neglect of credit composition.
source_files: The Journal of Finance - March 1974 - Towey - MONEY CREATION AND THE THEORY OF THE BANKING FIRM.md
question_context: The traditional theory of money creation posits that total demand deposits are determined by cash reserves and the reserve ratio, with a multiple expansion process. However, this theory has been criticized for treating bank responses mechanically and ignoring their role as profit-maximizing firms. Key formula: The equilibrium money stock results from interaction between the public's tastes and banks' price-output decisions. The text highlights that the public's shifts to currency or banks with different reserve ratios significantly influence total deposits. Additionally, using nominal quantity of deposits as bank output is questioned due to its neglect of credit composition and multidimensional deposit yields. The theory's shortcomings are addressed by integrating microeconomic models of firm behavior into banking analysis.

question: Based on the U.S. pairs trading evidence, which of the following factors are statistically significant determinants of cross-sectional pairs trading profitability?
options: A) High idiosyncratic volatility within pairs
B) High Amihud illiquidity within pairs
C) High newswire coverage within pairs
D) High analyst coverage within pairs
source_files: On-the-determinants-of-pairs-trading-profitab_2015_Journal-of-Financial-Mark.md
question_context: The study examines pairs trading profitability using daily stock price data from NYSE/AMEX (1960-2008), filtering for stocks with market capitalization above median and no missing returns. Key formula: The Amihud illiquidity ratio is computed as $\frac{|r_t|}{Volume_t}$ where $r_t$ is daily return and $Volume_t$ is in millions. Panel B of Table 5 shows that pairs with high idiosyncratic volatility generate 43 bps higher monthly returns than low-volatility pairs (t-stat=5.12), and high-illiquidity pairs outperform by 19 bps (t-stat=2.49). However, the difference in returns based on bid-ask spreads (4 bps, t-stat=0.56) and firm size (11 bps, t-stat=1.41) were not statistically significant. Newswire and analyst coverage showed inverse relationships with profitability, with less visible pairs outperforming by 30-40 bps, but these were not among the strongest drivers identified in the study.

question: Which of the following factors were found to significantly influence the 'flight home effect' in syndicated loan markets during the COVID-19 pandemic?
options: A) Expansionary monetary policy in the lender's country
B) Higher proportion of non-performing loans in the bank's portfolio
C) Development status of the borrower's country
D) Government restrictions in the lender's country
source_files: The-flight-home-effect-during-the-COVID-19-pandemic-_2025_Journal-of-Financi.md
question_context: Our estimates show that smaller, less capitalized banks with a higher proportion of non-performing loans are more likely to rebalance towards domestic borrowers. This channel is not surprising, since banks’ bailout likelihood increases with the proportion of domestic loans in their portfolios (Giannetti and Laeven, 2012a). Hence, we propose a plausible mechanism for the flight home effect, where banks with a higher probability to receive a bailout increase their home bias. Our estimates show that tougher restrictions in the lender country limit the banks’ shift towards domestic borrowers. Arguably, the freeze in domestic economic activity induces banks to explore lending opportunities abroad. On the other hand, expansionary monetary policy (in the form of lower repo rates and open market purchases) reinforces the lenders’ flight towards domestic borrowers. According to our findings, the flight home effect is not driven by international banks’ desire to rebalance their portfolios towards borrowers of higher quality, as development status and institutional quality in the host country are irrelevant for the banks’ flight to domestic borrowers.

question: In the context of Reisman's result on approximate factor structures, which of the following conditions are necessary to establish that expected returns are approximately linear in the betas on a proxy P?
options: A) Returns conform to an approximate factor structure
B) The proxy P is correlated with the factor F
C) There exists a riskless asset
D) The asset pricing functional is continuous
source_files: The Journal of Finance - September 1992 - SHANKEN - The Current State of the Arbitrage Pricing Theory.md
question_context: The approximate factor model assumes that the infinite sequence of asset returns conforms to an approximate factor structure. The key result is that if returns conform to such a structure and there is no arbitrage, then expected returns are approximately linear in the betas on any proxy P that is correlated with the factor F. This is derived using the transitivity of the approximate equality relation and the approximate proportionality of betas on F and P. The proof leverages Lemma 2, which states that if returns conform to an approximate factor structure, then the betas on P are approximately proportional to the betas on F, provided P and F are correlated. The assumption of no arbitrage is necessary for the APT result but not for Lemma 2. Notably, the existence of a riskless asset or continuity of the asset pricing functional is not required, contrasting with Reisman's original development.

Notably, the existence of a riskless asset or continuity of the asset pricing functional is not required, contrasting with Reisman's original development.

question: Based on the nonparametric statistical analysis of wheat, corn, and soybeans futures markets, which of the following conclusions are supported by the evidence?
options: A) Commodity futures prices are unbiased estimates of future spot prices
B) The theory of normal backwardation holds to varying degrees across markets and time periods
C) Large wheat speculators exhibit superior forecasting ability on average
D) Risk premiums have become less prominent in recent years compared to earlier years
source_files: The Journal of Finance - March 1985 - CHANG - Returns to Speculators and the Theory of Normal Backwardation.md
question_context:
This paper employs a nonparametric statistical procedure to examine the existence of a positive profit to speculators in wheat, corn, and soybeans futures markets. Specifically, we examine in what forms such 'profits' were rewarded. We presented statistical evidence in support of the theory of normal backwardation as suggested by Keynes. Moreover, we showed that the validity of the theory seems to be in different degrees in different markets and in different periods. The presence of such risk premiums tends to be more prominent in recent years than in earlier years.

We also showed that 'large wheat speculators' as a whole possessed some superior forecasting ability. In general, the commodity futures market rewards such skill; however, no attempt was made to estimate the relative size of the two rewards. Both findings show that large speculators, on the average, were consistent winners in futures markets. In sum, the evidence is inconsistent with the hypothesis that commodity futures prices are unbiased estimates of the corresponding future spot prices.

question: According to the empirical findings in the study, which of the following conditions are necessary for family firms to exhibit a performance advantage over nonfamily firms?
options: A) Presence of strong labor market regulation (LMR)
B) Absence of labor market regulation (LMR)
C) High levels of investor protection
D) Low variation in employment levels
source_files: Family Firms and Labor Market Regulation.md
question_context: The study demonstrates that family firms on average enjoy performance advantages over nonfamily firms only when labor markets are less regulated. This result is confirmed using a matched firm sample and a survey-based instrument for family control. Additionally, family firms exhibit lower variation in employment levels in less-regulated labor markets, supporting the notion that labor relations drive family firms’ performance advantages. The paper’s main hypothesis is that the absence of formal labor market regulation potentially induces a relative performance advantage for family firms. Key formula used in the analysis: $$y_{i t}=\alpha+\beta_{1}X_{i}+\beta_{2}Y_{c t-1}+\beta_{3}X_{i}\times Y_{i t-1}+\gamma^{\prime}Z_{i t-1}+\Lambda+\varepsilon_{i t},$$ where $X_{i}$ is a family ownership dummy, $Y_{c t-I}$ is LMR in country $c$ in year $t{-}1$, and $Z_{i t-I}$ are firm-level control variables.

question: In the context of trust-mediated money management, which of the following statements are supported by the model presented by Gennaioil, Shleifer, and Vishny?
options: A) Trust reduces the investor's subjective perception of investment risk, enabling managers to charge higher fees.
B) Managers consistently outperform the market net of fees due to their superior investment strategies.
C) Trust causes managers to pander to investor biases, especially in hot asset classes.
D) Investors who trust their managers achieve higher expected returns than they would by investing on their own.
source_files: The Journal of Finance - 2014 - GENNAIOLI - Money Doctors.md
question_context: The model presents a framework where trust in money managers reduces an investor’s perception of the riskiness of a given investment, allowing managers to charge fees that do not fall to costs. In equilibrium, fees are higher for assets with higher expected return, and managers on average underperform the market net of fees. However, investors still prefer hiring managers due to reduced anxiety and higher expected returns compared to investing on their own. When investors hold biased expectations, trust causes managers to pander to these beliefs, leading to distortions in investment allocation. The model also highlights that managers have incentives to pander to investor biases, especially in hot sectors, due to the benefits of attracting more funds and charging higher fees. Key formula: Fees are proportional to expected returns, with higher fees in asset classes with higher risk and return.

question: According to the text, which of the following practices undermine the scientific integrity of financial economics research?
options: A) Using language such as 'this result is encouraging' in research papers
B) Publishing only clinical trials with positive outcomes while suppressing negative results
C) Conducting sponsored research without disclosing potential conflicts of interest
D) Prefacing research conclusions with statements about probable error in opinions
source_files: The Journal of Finance - 2017 - HARVEY - Presidential Address  The Scientific Outlook in Financial Economics.md
question_context: The scientific outlook of financial economics crucially depends on our research and publication culture. As Hubble (1954, p. 41) argues, the scientist explores the world of phenomena by successive approximations, knowing that data are not precise and theories must always be tested. Importantly, you are not a sales person—you are a scientist. Yet how many of our papers include language such as 'this result is encouraging?' Such language is unscientific and reveals to the reader that the researcher has a specific agenda to find evidence in support of his or her hypothesis. This is the type of culture that motivates my address.\n\nWe are living in an era of increased mistrust about scientific discovery. Some of this mistrust is well founded. It is hard to interpret the results of pharmaceutical clinical trials, for instance, when those that do not work out are not made public. In our own field, credibility suffered after the global financial crisis when the documentary Inside Job suggested that sponsored research potentially misled investors. It is hard to undo such damage. Whether it is the widely discredited study that claimed power lines cause cancer or the fraudulent study in The Lancet that argued there is a link between the preservative in vaccines and autism, it is difficult to debunk bad science.
